facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the Judgment and Order dated the 15th July, 1953, of the Election Tribunal, Nagpur, in Election Petition No. 3 of 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the Judgment and Order dated the 15th July, 1953, of the Election Tribunal, Nagpur, in Election Petition No. 3 of 1952.

facts.text: The contest before the tribunal was about two seats in the Bhandara Parliamentary Constituency.

anchor.surface_text: The contest before the tribunal was about two seats in the Bhandara Parliamentary Constituency.

facts.text: The elections were held on five days in December, 1951, and January, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The elections were held on five days in December, 1951, and January, 1952.

facts.text: Thirteen candidates filed nomination papers, among them the petitioner.

anchor.surface_text: Thirteen candidates filed nomination papers, among them the petitioner. Of these, six contested the seat reserved for the Scheduled Castes.

facts.text: Six contested the seat reserved for the Scheduled Castes, one was Gangaram Thaware who has since died.

anchor.surface_text: Of these, six contested the seat reserved for the Scheduled Castes. -One of these was Gangaram Thaware who has since died.

facts.text: The Scheduled Caste in question is the Mahar caste.

anchor.surface_text: The Scheduled Caste in question is the Mahar caste. Objection was taken to Thawares nomination for the reserved seat on the ground that he was not a Mahar.

facts.text: It is admitted that Gangaram Thaware was born a Mahar.

anchor.surface_text: It is admitted that he was born a Mahar, but later in life he joined the Mahanubhava Panth.

facts.text: Gangaram Thaware later joined the Mahanubhava Panth.

anchor.surface_text: but later in life he joined the Mahanubhava Panth. This, according to the appellant, is a sect which does not believe in caste,

facts.text: Objection to Thaware's nomination succeeded and it was rejected.

anchor.surface_text: The objection succeeded and his nomination was rejected.

facts.text: The Election Tribunal held that the rejection of Gangaram Thaware's nomination was improper as he continued to be a member of the Mahar caste.

anchor.surface_text: The Election Tribunal held that the rejection of Gangaram Thawares nomination was improper as he continued to be a member of the Mahar caste despite his conversion to the tenets of the Mahanubhava. Panth.

facts.text: The two who were elected were Tularam Sakhare for the Scheduled Caste seat, and Chaturbhuj Jasani for the general seat.

anchor.surface_text: The two who were eligible for the reserved seat. The two who were elected were Tularam Sakhare, for the Scheduled Caste seat, and chaturbhuj, Jasani, for the general seat.

facts.text: Jasanis election was challenged on the ground that he was subject to disqualifications under section 7(d) of the Representation of the People Act, 1951 as he was interested in a contract for supply of goods to Central Government.

anchor.surface_text: Jasanis election was challenged on the ground that he was subject to the disqualifications set out in section 7  d  of the Representation of the People Act  Act XLIII of 1951  as he was interested in a contract for the supply of goods to the Central Government.

facts.text: Election Tribunal held that Chaturbhuj Jasani had a contract with the Central Government, so he was disqualified and set aside the whole election.

anchor.surface_text: It also held that Chaturbhuj Jasani had a contract with the Central Government, so he was disqualified. Accordingly it set aside the whole election.

facts.text: Chaturbhuj Jasani was and still is a partner in the firm of Moolji Sicka Company.

anchor.surface_text: Chaturbhuj Jasani was, and still is, a partner in the firm of Moolji Sicka Company, and it is said that at all material times the firm had- a contract for the supply of bidis to the Government for the troops.

facts.text: Moolji Sicka Company is a firm of bidi manufacturers.

anchor.surface_text: Moolji Sicka Company is a firm of bidi manufacturers. The Central Government was interested in stocking and purchasing bidis for sale to its troops through its canteens.

facts.text: Crucial dates are 15th November, 1951, the last date for nominations, and 14th February, 1952, the date results were declared.

anchor.surface_text: The crucial dates with which we are concerned are 15th November, 1951, the last date for putting in the nominations, and 14th February, 1952, the date on which the results were declared.

facts.text: Exhibit C shows Moolji Sicka Company had contracts for sale of bidis to Canteen Stores between relevant dates, with orders placed e.g. 8-10-1951, invoices 18-10-1951, payments later.

anchor.surface_text: Exhibit C is a tabular statement which sets out the dealings between the parties during certain months. ... Date of order Date of invoice Price of Date of by and goods pay- Canteen Stores Despatch. supplied.ment. 8-10-1951 18-10-1951Rs. 1,684-13-919-12-1951.

facts.text: On 15th November 1951, goods worth Rs. 84,659-14-3 had still to be paid for by Government to Moolji Sicka Company.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, on 15th November, 1951, goods worth Rs. 84,659-14-3 had still to be paid for. Then between 15th November, 1951, and 14th. February, 1952, further orders for goods valued at Rs. 39,695-8-9 were placed And accepted

facts.text: Supreme Court holds contracts subsisted on crucial dates and Jasani had share/interest as partner, disqualifying him under s.7(d).

anchor.surface_text: We hold therefore that these contracts which Moolji Sicka Company had entered into with the Government subsisted on 15th November, 1951, and on 14th February, 1952, and that as Chatturbhuj Jasani, the appellant, was a partner in the firm he also had both a share and an interest in them on the crucial dates.

facts.text: Gangaram Thaware continued to be a Mahar despite joining Mahanubhava Panth; his nomination wrongly rejected.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, applying the test in Abraham v. Abraham 1 , we hold that despite his conversion he continued to be a Mahar and so his nomination form was wrongly rejected.

facts.text: Gangaram Thaware was twice married to Mahar girls.

anchor.surface_text: Now considering Gangaram Thaware the individual we find that he was twice married and on both occasions to Mahar girls who were not Mahanubhavas at the time of their respective marriages.

facts.text: In 1936 Gangaram Thaware contested election for Provincial Assembly as Mahar candidate.

anchor.surface_text: The evidence also discloses that Gangaram Thaware led Mahar agitations and processions as a member and leader of the Mahar caste. In 1936 he contested the election for the Provincial Assembly as a Mahar candidate.

issues.text: Does a person who has fully executed his part of a contract continue to have an interest in it till the goods are paid for?

anchor.surface_text: It was said on behalf of the appellant that these are the only dates which are crucial, so if Moolji Sicka Company had fully executed their part of the contracts before the two crucial dates the disqualification would not apply. That raises these questions 1 Does a person who has fully executed his part of a contract continue to have an interest in it till the goods are paid for ?

issues.text: The only question here is whether he ceased to be a Mahar when he joined the Mahanubhava Panth.

anchor.surface_text: We now turn to Gangaram Thaware. He stood as a Scheduled Caste candidate and his nomination was rejected on the ground that he did not belong to the Scheduled Caste in question, namely the Mahars. The only question here is whether he ceased to be a Mahar when he joined the Mahanubhava Panth.

anchor.surface_text: It was said that the contract was embodied in four letters. We do not intend to analyse these letters in detail. here. It is enough to say that in our opinion no binding engagement can be spelt out of them except to this extent Moolji Sicka Company undertook to sell to the canteen contractors only through the Canteen Stores and not direct and undertook to pay a commission on all sales.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Letters set readiness terms but no engagement until order accepted; each order creates distinct contract per commercial practice.

holdings.text: A contract for supply of goods continues until fully discharged by performance on both sides, including payment, so interest subsists till payment even after supply.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Debt depends on contract terms; possibility of dispute requires enforcing contract; distinguishes English cases on different statutes.

holdings.text: Contracts subsisted on crucial dates of 15th November 1951 and 14th February 1952; Jasani as partner had share and interest, disqualifying him under s.7(d).

anchor.surface_text: We hold therefore that these contracts which Moolji Sicka Company had entered into with the Government subsisted on 15th November, 1951, and on 14th February, 1952, and that as Chatturbhuj Jasani, the appellant, was a partner in the firm he also had both a share and an interest in them on the crucial dates.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence of pending payments, new orders, consignment guarantees between dates; partner interest imputed.

holdings.text: Contracts not void under Article 299(1) for disqualification under s.7(d); non-compliance prevents Government suit but valid otherwise, protected by ss.230(3), 236 ICA.

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly hold that the contracts in question here are not void simply because the Union Government could not have been sued on them by reason of article 299(1).

holdings.reasoning_summary: Provision directory for third parties to protect Government from unauthorized acts/suits but not invalidate; applies Contract Act protections; purposive to avoid injustice.

holdings.text: Election Tribunal right in disqualifying Chaturbhuj Jasani under s.7(d).

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the Election Tribunal was right in disqualifying Chatturbhuj Jasani.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Upheld findings on subsisting contracts and partner interest unaffected by Art.299.

holdings.text: Gangaram Thaware continued as Mahar despite joining Mahanubhava Panth; nomination wrongly rejected.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, applying the test in Abraham v. Abraham, we hold that despite his conversion he continued to be a Mahar and so his nomination form was wrongly rejected.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applied Abraham test: old body reaction tolerant, convert intention/conduct retained ties (marriages, elections, agitations), new sect rules allow; no severance.

anchor.surface_text: It was said that the contract was embodied in four letters. We do not intend to analyse these letters in detail. here. It is enough to say that in our opinion no binding engagement can be spelt out of them except to this extent Moolji Sicka Company undertook to sell to the canteen contractors only through the Canteen Stores and not direct and undertook to pay a commission on all sales.

In our opinion, the Election Tribunal was-right in disqualifying Chatturbhuj Jasani. We number turn to Gangaram Thaware. He stood as a Scheduled Caste candidate and his numberination was rejected on the ground that he did number belong to the Scheduled Caste in question, namely the Mahars.

anchor.surface_text: We hold therefore that these contracts which Moolji Sicka Company had entered into with the Government subsisted on 15th November, 1951, and on 14th February, 1952, and that as Chatturbhuj Jasani, the appellant, was a partner in the firm he also had both a share and an interest in them on the crucial dates.

In our opinion, the Election Tribunal was-right in disqualifying Chatturbhuj Jasani. We number turn to Gangaram Thaware. He stood as a Scheduled Caste candidate and his numberination was rejected on the ground that he did number belong to the Scheduled Caste in question, namely the Mahars.
We accordingly hold that the contracts in question here are not void simply because the Union Government could not have been sued on them by reason of article 299(1).

In our opinion, the Election Tribunal was-right in disqualifying Chatturbhuj Jasani. We number turn to Gangaram Thaware. He stood as a Scheduled Caste candidate and his numberination was rejected on the ground that he did number belong to the Scheduled Caste in question, namely the Mahars.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, applying the test in Abraham v. Abraham, we hold that despite his conversion he continued to be a Mahar and so his nomination form was wrongly rejected.

In our opinion, the Election Tribunal was-right in disqualifying Chatturbhuj Jasani. We number turn to Gangaram Thaware. He stood as a Scheduled Caste candidate and his numberination was rejected on the ground that he did number belong to the Scheduled Caste in question, namely the Mahars.
